Nitrogen-doped carbon composites are prepared using simple precursors, such as glucose or urea and used as supports for Fe nanoparticles. The present work investigated two approaches for incorporating metal nanoparticles into the composite: traditional metal postloading and in situ formation of a metal/N-doped carbon catalyst. The impacts of the preparation technique on (i) the characteristics of the resulting iron oxides (Fe2O3 and Fe3O4) and (ii) the nanoparticle distribution on the support were determined. Microscopic surface characterization revealed that the postloading method promoted a uniform distribution of Fe nanoparticles (5–10 nm), which enhanced the activity and long-term stability of the catalytic system for the Baeyer–Villiger oxidation of cyclic ketones. The product yield reached 97% (5 h, 60 °C), and after the third reaction cycle, the yield remained at 96%. The proposed synthetic approach for preparing active and stable catalysts provides a new perspective for the inexpensive and sustainable synthesis of lactones. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords N Fe-doped material Heterogenous catalyst Baeyer–Villiger oxidation Cyclic ketone Lactone Iron oxides Nitrogen-doping Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction There is an urgent need to mitigate environmental issues concerning the safety of waste disposal, which can be addressed via modified oxidation processes [1–5], particularly, the Baeyer–Villiger oxidation (BVO) of cyclic ketones to lactones. Lactones are key reagents for the synthesis of antibiotics, steroids, and pheromones, and they can also serve as monomers for polymerization [1,6]. The BVO of cyclic ketones typically uses peracids, hydrogen peroxide, or molecular oxygen as the oxidant. However, peracids are expensive and hazardous (i.e., shock sensitive), which restricts their utility in industrial applications. Meanwhile, the use of H2O2 requires a catalyst (usually transition metal-based systems comprising Pt, Re, or Ti) to increase its nucleophilicity [7]. Industrial methods for producing ε-caprolactone (i.e., the key monomer used for polymerization) use peracetic acid as the oxidant. However, industrial-grade peracetic acid is much more expensive than H2O2 and contains up to 45% acetic acid (for stabilization), which must be neutralized. Therefore, the oxidation process generates significant waste. Moreover, the transport and storage of peracetic acid is severely curtailed, thus severely limiting its use. Consequently, increasing attention has been focused on the in situ generation of organic peracids while avoiding the direct handling of peracid. The relatively safe one-pot oxidation of cyclohexanone in the presence of acetaldehyde and oxygen can be employed as an alternative industrial method for the production of ε-caprolactone [1,6,7]. Other aldehydes, such as benzaldehyde or isobutyraldehyde, can be used as reductants for the oxidation of cyclic ketones [8,9]. This process is typically catalyzed by Fe2O3 [10] or other iron compounds, such as iron-containing MCM-41, MCM-48 [11,12], or magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles [13]. Heterogeneous catalysts have clear advantages, such as their facile separation from the reaction mixture, reusability, and potential applicability in continuous flow processes that do not involve a separation step. However, they often suffer from low longevity because the active metal catalyst can leach from the solid support. Therefore, nitrogen-doped carbon materials have been investigated as convenient supports for metal/non-noble metal-based catalysts [14–16]. Nitrogen doping of the carbon support can enhance metal dispersion, metal−support interactions, and overall stability [14]. Considering economic and environmental factors, it is desirable to develop catalysts that can be prepared by simple and straightforward methods using natural, abundant, and renewable precursors [17–20]. Numerous cost-efficient precursors [21–37], such as saccharides [21–24], cellulose [25], wood [26], coconut shells [27], lignin [28], and spongin scaffolds [29] can be upgraded into carbon materials and N-doped carbon materials after post-treatment with ammonia or N-containing precursors. Alternatively, in situ pyrolysis of N-containing compounds such as melamine [30], amines [31], amino acids [32], phthalocyanines [33], ionic liquids [34], as well as biopolymeric precursors such as chitin [35], silk [36], hair [37] results in direct synthesis of N-doped carbon materials. Further modifying carbon materials with metal precursors enables the fabrication of functional composites that can be readily applied as heterogeneous catalysts. These systems exhibit excellent catalytic performance and stability owing to the various metal–support interactions induced by N-doping. In situ synthesis of metal/N-doped carbon catalysts is the simplest and most direct strategy for obtaining active composite catalysts [38–41]. In this approach, the carbon, metal, and nitrogen precursors are mixed together and then pyrolyzed. Although it is not a time-consuming procedure, it is difficult to control the size of the metal nanoparticles, and therefore, a wide nanoparticle size distribution is often obtained. In contrast, the traditional postloading method requires more synthetic steps because the metal catalyst is introduced onto previously prepared N-doped carbon material; however, the metal loading can be finely tuned by varying the concentration of the precursor solution [14]. Nevertheless, this method may also generate aggregated metal nanoparticles on the support surface, leading to decreased catalytic activity or catalyst leakage [42]. Fe/N-doped carbon composites prepared via direct synthesis from nitrogen- and iron-containing precursors or via impregnation have demonstrated effective catalytic activity for the ammoxidation of aromatic aldehydes to aromatic nitriles [38,39,43], the hydrodeoxygenation of m-cresol [44], and the oxidation of alkenes to ketones and 1,2-diketones [45]. In this work we have developed reusable Fe/N/C composites, which can be used to effectively synthesize different lactones through BVO. The novel composites are prepared using abundant and renewable (glucose) and inexpensive (urea) reagents using two approaches: (1) simple in situ incorporation of Fe nanoparticles through direct carbonization of the precursors and (2) postloading of the Fe nanoparticles on previously prepared N-doped carbon. A comparison of the catalysts obtained using each synthetic method reveals differences in activity and stability. Thus, we explore the effects of the preparation method on the characteristics of the derived N-doped carbon-supported Fe composites and elucidate their relationships to the catalytic BVO activity. The Fe/N/C composites represent efficient and inexpensive green catalysts that exhibit excellent conversion, selectivity, and stability and can be obtained under mild and solvent free conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Iron(III) oxide, iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate, glucose, urea, cyclohexanone, 2-methylcyclohexanone, 4-methylcyclohexanone, 4-tert-butylcyclohexanone, cyclopentanone, and 2-adamantanone were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The iron content in each Fe/N/C catalyst sample was determined based on inductively-coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) using a Varian 710-ES spectrometer (Varian, Palo Alto, CA, USA) equipped with a OneNeb nebulizer and a twister glass spray chamber. Gas chromatography (GC) analyses were carried out using a SHIMADZU GC-2010 Plus with a Zebron ZB-5MSi column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm film) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). Elemental analysis (EA) was performed using a Flash 2000 thermal conductivity detector (TCD). XPS measurements were performed with an ultra-high-vacuum (UHV) multi-chamber experimental setup comprising a PREVAC EA15 hemispherical electron energy analyzer fitted with a 2D multi-channel plate detector. The system base pressure was 9·10−9 Pa, and an Al-Kα X-ray source (PREVAC dual-anode XR-40B source, excitation energy = 1486.60 eV) was used to excite the sample. The pass energy (PE) was set to 200 eV for survey spectral collection (scanning step = 0.9 eV) or 100 eV for high-resolution energy regions (scanning step = 0.06 eV). All measurements were performed with a normal take-off angle and a curved analyzer exit slit (0.8 × 25 mm) selected for the highest energy resolution. The binding energy scale of the analyzer was calibrated to the Au 4f7/2 (84.0 eV) region of the gold-covered sample placed on the same sample stage [46]. The acquired spectra were fitted using CASA XPS® software. The components were fitted with a sum of Gaussian (30%) and Lorenz (70%) functions, while a Shirley function was applied for the background subtraction (unless otherwise noted). Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) investigations were done on a S/TEM Titan 80–300 FEI microscope, operating at 300 kV. The preparation of samples was performed as follows: samples were crushed in an agate mortar, the obtained powders were dispersed in ethanol using an ultrasonic bath, and then droplets of such prepared dispersions were put onto a microscopic grid covered with a lacey carbon film and dried at room temperature. For catalyst characterization TEM Bright Field (TEM-BF), Dark Field (TEM-DF), High Resolution TEM (HRTEM) and Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM) High-Angle Annular Dark-Field (HAADF) images were collected. Electron diffraction patterns were recorded using diffraction aperture (Selected Area Electron Diffraction, SAED). 2.2 Catalyst preparation In situ prepared Fe/N-doped composites (Fe insitu @NC-T, where T = preparation temperature): The appropriate masses of glucose, urea, iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate, and LUDOX® HS-40 were combined (an equivalent mass of silica was used, relative to all components of the mixture). The mixture was stirred for 2 h in an ultrasonic bath and then dried using a rotary evaporator. The obtained yellow powder was pyrolyzed at 900 °C (yield 6.9%), 800 °C (yield 7.8%), or 700 °C (yield 10.2%) for 2 h at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a flow of argon. Finally, the silica nanoparticles were removed used an aqueous solution of NH4HF2 (4 mol L−1), and the catalyst was isolated by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried at 100 °C. Postloaded Fe on N-doped carbon catalysts (Fe postloaded @NC-T, where T = preparation temperature): These catalysts were prepared in two stages: template preparation and then wet impregnation with aqueous Fe(NO3)3. First, a mixture of 5 g urea, 1 g glucose, and 15 g LUDOX® HS-40 was stirred for 2 h in an ultrasonic bath and then dried using a rotary evaporator. The obtained white powder was pyrolyzed at 900 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a flow of argon. Next, the silica nanoparticles were removed using an aqueous solution of NH4HF2 (4 mol L−1). The templates were isolated via filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried at 100 °C (yield 6.3%). The second stage involved wet impregnation with an aqueous Fe(NO3)3 solution. The mixture of N-doped carbon was stirred with an appropriate amount of iron(III) nitrate nonahydrate in water for 2 h in an ultrasonic bath and then dried using a rotary evaporator and pyrolyzed at 450 °C under argon. An analogous composite material without nitrogen was synthesized in the same manner while omitting urea (labeled as Fe postloaded @C-900). 2.3 Baeyer–Villiger oxidation First, 200 mg of catalyst, 0.295 g (3 mmol) cyclohexanone, 0.955 g (9 mmol) benzaldehyde, 0.1 g n-decane (internal standard), and 10 mL acetonitrile were added to a 25 mL round-bottom flask. The mixture was saturated with oxygen, sealed under an oxygen atmosphere (balloon with oxygen was applied) and stirred (1000 rpm, 60 °C) for 1–5 h. The reaction progress was monitored by GC. The heterogeneous catalyst was recycled—for the catalyst recycling tests, all reactants and reagents were used in 5-fold larger scale relative to the screening tests. The catalyst was filtered off, washed with distilled water, dried under vacuum on a Schlenk line (60 °C, 0.1 mbar, 2 h) and used in the next cycle of the reaction. 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst preparation A series of iron nanocomposites was prepared via either in situ synthesis or Fe postloading. In the in situ protocol, environmentally benign glucose and inexpensive urea were mixed with aqueous Fe(NO3)3, which served as the carbon, nitrogen, and Fe sources, respectively. The relative contents of nitrogen and Fe in the products were varied by changing the mass ratio of the precursors to find the most suitable composition for high catalytic activity. LUDOX® silica nanoparticles were added as a hard template to endow the final composite material with sufficient porosity. The mixture was sonicated, dried, and pyrolyzed under an Ar atmosphere at various temperatures. The hard silica template was removed by acid etching, and the as prepared iron composites catalysts were labeled as Feinsitu@NC-T (where T = pyrolysis temperature, i.e. 700, 800, or 900 °C). In the postloading protocol, the N-doped carbon support (NC-900) was prepared following the pyrolysis of glucose, urea, and LUDOX® HS-40 (previously dried) at 900 °C. After the silica nanoparticles were removed, the support underwent wet impregnation with an aqueous Fe(NO3)3 solution, followed by drying and pyrolysis at 450 °C under argon. This catalyst was labeled as Fe postloaded @NC-900. For comparison, the analogous composite material without nitrogen doping was synthesized by pyrolyzing glucose with LUDOX® HS-40, followed by wet impregnation with iron, as previously described (labeled as Fe postloaded @C-900). 3.2 Catalyst characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to evaluate the structures of the nanocomposites prepared via in situ and postloading methods. Fig. 1 compares the bright-field (TEM-BF), dark-field (TEM-DF), and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) images. The differences between the catalysts obtained from each method are most noticeable in the SAED patterns. The Feinsitu@NC-900 composite had an amorphous structure. The SAED image shows three blurry rings, which correspond to the (002), (10), and (11) bands of graphite. These features are characteristic of carbon materials with a turbostratic structure, i.e., comprising highly defective carbon layers with random orientation. The red arrows indicate single reflections from iron oxide nanoparticles. Therefore, the analyzed material is composed of crystalline iron nanoparticles deposited on a turbostratic carbon support. Only some iron nanoparticles (those close to Bragg orientation and selected by the diffraction aperture) are visible in the DF image as bright spots. To assess the real quantity and distribution of iron oxide nanoparticles in that case is better to use the HAADF detector, more sensitive to chemical contrast (recorded intensity is proportional to the atomic number Z). An example of obtained image can be found in the Supporting Information (Fig. S1a). Due to the large difference in the atomic number between Fe (Z = 26) and C (Z = 6), nanoparticles containing iron (5–30 nm) are clearly visible on the carbon support (regardless of their orientation). The HRTEM images (Fig. S1b,c) reveal that the structure of the carbon support is composed of carbon layers that are severely damaged. However, some layers are arranged approximately parallel at a constant distance from one another (∼0.35 nm). The Fe postloaded @C-900 and Fe postloaded @NC-900 materials had polycrystalline (nanocrystalline) structures, where the crystallite size was larger for Fe postloaded @C-900. According to SAED results, the nanocomposite without N-doping contained Fe2O3 (hematite, hexagonal, R-3c space group) [47], whereas the nanocomposite with N-doping contained Fe3O4 nanoparticles (magnetite, cubic, Fd-3 m space group) [48]. DF images confirmed that iron oxide particles are the dominant component in both postloaded samples (the results do not indicate the presence of a carbon component), and they are of uniform size and random orientation. The bright points in the DF images are only some of the iron oxide nanoparticles (those close to Bragg orientation and selected by the diffraction aperture). The darker regions correspond to other iron oxide particles (with different crystallographic orientations). The TEM-BF images (Fig. S2) show that Fe postloaded @C-900 is composed of interconnected crystalline particles (∼10–20 nm) comprising a highly porous structure. The structure of Fe postloaded @NC-900 (Fig. S3) is similar, although in this case, the particles are significantly smaller (5–10 nm). The materials prepared by the iron postloading method and iron in situ incorporation also had different extents of N-doping. The nitrogen content (determined by EA) of the materials prepared by in situ carbonization of precursors decreased as the carbonization temperature increased (from 5.6% for material carbonized at 700 °C to <1% for the material synthesized at 900 °C), what is associated with elimination of nitrogen, but also hydrogen and oxygen species on increasing the temperature. According to XPS analysis, which provides more surface data relative to EA, the nitrogen loading was 8.2% at 700 °C and 2.7% at 900 °C. Despite the use of the same ratio of glucose to urea precursors (glucose:urea = 1:2.5 wt.), when preparing Fe postoloaded @NC-900 and Feinsitu@NC-900 composites, the postloaded iron product had a significantly higher nitrogen content (9.5% vs. <1% for Feinsitu@NC-900), which suggested enhanced nitrogen elimination in the presence of iron precursor [49]. Differences in Fe loading observed with EA and XPS analysis ( Table 1) are also most probably caused by the fact that XPS analysis provides more surface data relative to EA. The chemical environments of iron and nitrogen species in the near-surface regions of the composites were further examined by XPS. The high-resolution N 1s spectrum of Fe postoloaded @NC-900 was decomposed into four peaks at 396.5, 398.7, 400.2, and 402.8 eV, corresponding to Fe−Nx, pyridinic, pyrrolic, and graphitic nitrogen, respectively ( Fig. 2a). The peak at 396.5 eV is consistent with a previously reported value [50] and is common for nitrides of various compounds. This result confirmed that Fe coordinates to N, thereby further stabilizing the active catalyst. Before wet impregnation, the support (i.e., NC-900) only contained pyridinic, pyrrolic, and graphitic nitrogen, as expected (Fig. S5). The Fe−Nx interactions were also observed on the Fe 2p spectrum (peak at 708.9 eV), as shown in Fig. 2b. Moreover, primary peaks related to Fe 2p3/2 at 706.6, 710.7, and 713.4 eV confirmed the presence of metallic Fe and Fe oxides, respectively. Additional satellite peaks were observed at binding energies > 714.0 eV. The fitted peaks above 720 eV were attributed to the respective Fe 2p1/2 counterparts of the Fe 2p region. The peaks corresponding to the mixture of Fe2+ and Fe3+ oxides (710.7 and 713.4 eV, respectively) confirmed the presence of Fe3O4 oxides with a minor contribution from heavily defected Fe2O3 [51] in the postloaded composite. These results are consistent with the SAED analysis, which confirmed that Fe3O4 is the only or (at least) dominant component in that material. In contrast to composites prepared via postloading Fe (Fe postoloaded @NC-900), the N 1s spectrum of the composite material where Fe was incorporated in situ (Feinsitu@NC-900; Fig. S6e) was impossible to decompose because of the weak nitrogen signal intensity (due to the very low nitrogen content, i.e., <1% by EA, 2.69% by XPS). The Fe−Nx configuration was observed in the Fe 2p3/2 spectrum at 709.8 eV, and the remaining peaks at 706.9, 711.69, and 712.90 eV corresponded to metallic Fe and of Fe oxides, respectively (Fig. S6f). The shifts with respect to the postloaded sample most likely indicated significant charge relocation as a result of the technological process. The higher carbonization temperature of the composite materials prepared by the in situ approach influenced the content of various N-species and facilitated the formation of metallic Fe, as evidenced by the N 1s and Fe 2p spectra of materials synthesized at 700, 800, and 900°C (Fig. S6). The N 1 s spectra were decomposed into three peaks corresponding to pyridinic, pyrrolic, and graphitic nitrogen. These results do not exclude the minor presence of Fe−Nx species in the composite materials (observed mostly in Feinsitu@NC-800). However, further decomposition of the N 1s spectra would lead to uncertainty because of the weak signal intensity arising from the much lower nitrogen content at higher annealing temperatures. 3.3 Catalytic activity of Fe/N/C composites in Baeyer–Villiger oxidation To determine the most suitable amount of Fe catalyst in the composite material to promote the BVO of cyclic ketones, model reactions were performed using 1 or 2 wt% Fe2O3 catalyst to oxidize cyclohexanone with molecular oxygen (Fig. S4) [52]. Nearly complete substrate conversion was observed after 5 h with the 2 wt% catalyst, and therefore, composites with final Fe loadings of less than 2 wt% were fabricated and further investigated. The influence of catalyst loading was studied with nanocomposites prepared with 0.5, 1.5, or 2.0 wt% Fe (as determined by ICP-AES analysis) and carbonized at 900 °C ( Fig. 3). The initial studies were performed using nanocomposites prepared by the in situ synthetic approach. Upon increasing the catalyst loading, the reaction rate increased, and the product yield reached 97% after 5 h when using the composite with an iron loading of 2.0 wt%. Thus, the influence of the carbonization temperature (700, 800, or 900 °C) was investigated using composites loaded with ∼2 wt% Fe (as determined by ICP-AES analysis, Table 1, Fig. 3). A higher pyrolysis temperature resulted in a higher product yield (97% after 5 h using the catalyst synthesized at 900 °C). Next, the impact of the precursor ratio on the activity of the derived composites in Baeyer–Villiger oxidation was investigated by varying the precursor (glucose and urea) molar ratio (1:1, 1:2, or 1:2.5) (Table S1). The precursor ratio influenced the composition of the carbon support. Although the nitrogen doping obtained by the in situ approach was low (<0.73%), it increased as the proportion of urea precursor increased. The composite derived from 1:2.5 glucose:urea contained up to 0.73% nitrogen, whereas the nitrogen content of the composite derived from a 1:1 mixture of precursors was under the detection limit. Despite minimal differences in terms of nitrogen doping, the precursor ratio influenced the catalytic activity of the derived composites ( Fig. 4). The best performance was observed for the composite with the highest urea content in the precursor mixture (1:2.5), which afforded a 97% yield after 5 h, while having the lowest content of Fe species (1.99%). For comparison, the composite derived from 1:1 precursor ratio afforded a product with the yield of only 76%, despite higher content of Fe species of 2.34%. Additionally, the stability of the optimized composite catalyst (prepared by the in situ method) was studied in the model reaction, i.e., cyclohexanone oxidation. For these tests, the catalyst was separated after each reaction cycle, dried, and reused in the next reaction. High activity was achieved in the first reaction cycle; however, with each consecutive cycle, a noticeable reduction in the catalyst activity was observed (97% yield in the first cycle to 34% in the third cycle). The recycled catalyst was analyzed by ICP after each cycle, revealing a reduction in Fe content from 1.99% in the fresh catalyst to 1.16% in the catalyst after the third cycle. These experiments confirmed that significant iron leaching occurred when using the composite material synthesized by the in situ approach. For comparison, the nanocomposite prepared by the postloading method was used as the catalyst for the reaction (synthesized using optimized conditions for the in situ method, i.e., glucose:urea = 1:2.5, carbonized at 900 °C, followed by Fe wet impregnation to obtain a final nanocomposite with ∼2 wt% Fe). The postloaded Fe catalyst exhibited very similar performance to the catalyst prepared by the in situ method in terms of the oxidation of cyclohexanone to ε-caprolactone (99% yield after 5 h) in the first reaction cycle. The recycling experiments ( Fig. 5) revealed less Fe leaching in subsequent reaction cycles that in the in situ prepared catalyst. To verify the positive effect of N-doping on the stability and performance of the composites, the material without incorporated nitrogen atoms (Fe postloaded @C-900) was tested in the same catalytic oxidation experiments. In the first reaction cycle, this catalyst achieved slightly lower catalytic activity than the analogous catalyst with additional nitrogen sites; this distinction was attributed to the higher Fe content (2.29 wt% Fe in Fepostloaded@NC-900 and 1.49 wt% Fe in Fe postloaded @C-900). Moreover, the activity of the composite without N-doping decreased continuously in the subsequent reaction cycles, leading to a product yield of only 67% in the third reaction cycle, whereas the composite with additional N-doping (Fepostloaded@NC-900) afforded a product yield of 96%. The decreasing product yield observed for the Fepostloaded@C-900 composite was attributed to a greater degree of Fe leaching. After the third reaction cycle, the Fe loading had decreased to 0.58 wt% in the Fepostloaded@C-900 sample and only decreased to 1.71 wt% in the Fepostloaded@NC-900 sample. Therefore, the enhanced stability of the composite material was attributed to the presence of N-atoms, which promoted the uniform distribution of small (5–10 nm) Fe nanoparticles on the support. As demonstrated by theoretical calculations performed for Pt nanoparticles, the nitrogen-containing groups can act as active sites for the nucleation and growth of metal nanoparticles, stabilizing deposited nanoparticles with small size and narrow distribution [14,53,54]. These results highlight the significant influence of the preparation method on the Baeyer–Villiger oxidation performance of synthetic Fe composites. Despite having similar initial catalytic activities, the composite materials synthesized by Fe postloading, facilitated the formation of composites with polycrystalline structures more effectively than the composite synthesized in situ. This led to a significant number of Fe3O4 nanoparticles with a narrow size distribution and induced metallic Fe and Fe−Nx interactions that stabilized the catalyst. To verify the applicability of the described approach, the substrate scope of the reaction was explored ( Table 2) using various ketones (e.g., 2-methylcyclohexanone, 4-methylcyclohexanone, 4-tert-butylcyclohexanone, cyclopentanone, and 2-adamantanone). These ketones were oxidized with molecular oxygen in the presence of Fe postloaded @NC-900 to afford the desired product in high yields (>92%). 4 Conclusions This study examined the effects of different synthetic approaches on the activity and stability of Fe/N/C composites in the BVO of cyclic ketones. Compared with previous findings [6–9], the optimized catalyst described herein was very stable, and its selectivity and conversion of various cyclic ketones were higher over shorter reaction times. The main conclusions from this investigation are as follows: (i) nitrogen doping of carbon composites (using simple, abundant, inexpensive precursors) can enhance the catalytic stability of the supported metal; (ii) although the in situ catalyst preparation method is straightforward and simple, the stability of the obtained nanoparticles could be further enhanced when implementing a two-step iron postloading procedure; (iii) the composites prepared by wet impregnation of Fe exhibited high catalytic activity for the oxidation of ketones, affording the corresponding lactones in high yields (>92%) and remaining stable over several cycles. The preparation of stable catalysts will enable the development of more sustainable catalytic approaches (e.g., using flow chemistry), where the enhanced catalyst stability can improve green chemistry metrics. coredata.dc:description: Nitrogen-doped carbon composites are prepared using simple precursors, such as glucose or urea and used as supports for Fe nanoparticles. The present work investigated two approaches for incorporating metal nanoparticles into the composite: traditional metal postloading and in situ formation of a metal/N-doped carbon catalyst. The impacts of the preparation technique on (i) the characteristics of the resulting iron oxides (Fe2O3 and Fe3O4) and (ii) the nanoparticle distribution on the support were determined. Microscopic surface characterization revealed that the postloading method promoted a uniform distribution of Fe nanoparticles (5–10 nm), which enhanced the activity and long-term stability of the catalytic system for the Baeyer–Villiger oxidation of cyclic ketones. The product yield reached 97% (5 h, 60 °C), and after the third reaction cycle, the yield remained at 96%. The proposed synthetic approach for preparing active and stable catalysts provides a new perspective for the inexpensive and sustainable synthesis of lactones.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active and stable catalysts for Baeyer–Villiger oxidation – Traditional postloading vs in situ synthesis of Fe/N/C nanoparticles
